THE INTRODUCTION TO PART THE THIRD.</br>Listen!  ye know that I am mad,</br>And ye will listen! — wizard dreams</br>Were with me! — all is true that seems!—</br>From dreams alone can truth be had—</br>In dreams divinest lore is taught,</br>For the eye, no more distraught,</br>Rests most calmly, and the ear,</br>Of sound unconscious, may apply</br>Its attributes unknown, to hear</br>The music of philosophy!</br>Thus am I wisest in my sleep,</br>For thoughts and things, which day light brings,</br>Come to the spirit sad and single,</br>But verse and prose, and joys and woes</br>Inextricably mingle,</br>When the hushed frame is silent in repose!</br>Twilight and moonlight, mist and storm,</br>Black night, and fire-eyed hurricane,</br>And crested lightning, and, the snows</br>That mock the sunbeams, and the rain</br>Which bounds on earth with big drops warm,</br>All are round me while I spell</br>The legend of sweet Christabel!

CHRISTABEL, PART THIRD.</br>Nine moons have waxed, and the tenth, in its wane,</br>Sees Christabel struggle in unknown pain!</br>—For many moons was her eye less bright,</br>For many moons was her vest more tight,</br>And her cheek was pale, save when, with a start,</br>The life blood came from the panting heart,</br>And fluttering, o'er that thin fair face</br>Past with a rapid nameless pace,</br>And at moments a big tear filled the eye,</br>And at moments a short and smothered sigh</br>Swelled her breast with sudden strain,</br>Breathed half in grief, and half in pain,</br>For her's are pangs, on the rack that wind</br>The outward frame and the inward mind.</br>—And when at night she did visit the oak,</br>She wore the Baron's scarlet cloak,</br>(That cloak which happy to hear and to tell</br>Was lined with the fur of the leopard well,)</br>And as she wandered down the dell</br>None said 'twas the lady Christabel.—</br>Some thought 'twas a weird and ugsome elf,</br>Some deemed 'twas the sick old Baron himself,</br>Who wandered beneath the snowy lift</br>To count his beads in solemn shrift—</br>(For his shape below was wide to see</br>All bloated with the hydropsie.)</br>Oh!  had her old father the secret known,</br>He had stood as stark as the statue of stone</br>That stands so silent, and white, and tall,</br>At the upper end of his banquet hall!

Am I asleep or am I awake?</br>In very truth I oft mistake,</br>As the stories of old come over my brain,</br>And I build in spirit the mystic strain;—</br>Ah!  would to the virgin that I were asleep!</br>But I must wake, and I must weep!</br>Sweet Christabel, it is not well</br>That a lady, pure as the sunless snow</br>That lies so soft on the mountain's brow,</br>That a maiden of sinless chastity</br>In childbirth pangs should be doomed to die,</br>Or live with a name of sorrow and shame,</br>And hear the words of blemish and blame!</br>—For the world that smiles at the guilt of man,</br>Places woman beneath its ban;</br>Alas, that scandal thus should wreak</br>Its vengeance on the warm and weak,</br>That the arrows of the cold and dull</br>Should wound the breast of the beautiful!

Of the things that be did we know but half;</br>Many, and many would weep, who laugh!</br>Tears would darken many an eye,</br>Or that deeper grief, (when its orb is dry,</br>When it cannot dare the eye of day),</br>O'er the clouded heart would sway,</br>Till it crumbled like desert dust away!</br>But here we meet with grief and grudge,</br>And they who cannot know us, judge!</br>Thus, souls on whom good angels smile,</br>Are scoffed at in our world of guile—</br>Let this, Ladie, thy comfort be,</br>Man knows not us, good angels know</br>The things that pass in the world below;</br>And scarce, methinks, it seems unjust,</br>That the world should view thee with mistrust,</br>For who that saw that child of thine</br>Pale Christabel, who could divine</br>That its sire was the Ladie Geraldine?

But in I rush, with too swift a gale,</br>Into the ocean of my tale!</br>Not yet young Christabel, I ween,</br>Of her babe hath lighter been.</br>—'Tis the month of the snow and the blast;</br>And the days of Christmas mirth are past,</br>When the oak-roots heaped on the hearth blazed bright,</br>Casting a broad and dusky light</br>On the shadowy forms of the warriors old,</br>Who stared from the wall, most grim to behold—</br>On shields where the spider his tapestry weaves,</br>On the holly boughs and the ivy leaves,</br>The few green glories that still remain</br>To mock the storm and welcome the rain,</br>Brighter and livelier mid tempest and shower;</br>Like a hero in the battle hour!—</br>Brave emblems o'er the winter hearth,</br>They cheered our fathers' hours of mirth!—

Twelve solar months complete and clear</br>The magic circle of the year!</br>Each (the ancient riddle saith)</br>Children, two times thirty, hath!</br>Three times ten are fair and white,</br>Three times ten are black as night,</br>Three times ten hath Hecate,</br>Three times ten the God of day;</br>Thus spoke the old hierophant</br>(I saw her big breast swelling pant)</br>What time, I dreamed, in ghostly wise</br>Of Eleusinian mysteries,</br>For I am the hierarch</br>Of the mystical and dark—</br>And now, if rightly I do spell</br>Of the lady Christabel,</br>She hates the three times ten so white,</br>And sickens in their searching light,</br>And woe is hers — alas!  alack!</br>She hates the three times ten so black—</br>As a mastiff bitch doth bark,</br>I hear her moaning in the dark!—

'Tis the month of January,</br>Why lovely maiden, light and airy,</br>While the moon can scarcely glow,</br>Thro' the plumes of falling snow,</br>While the moss upon the bark</br>Is withered all, and damp, and dark,</br>While cold above the stars in doubt</br>Look dull, and scarcely will stay out,</br>While the snow is heavy on beechen bower</br>And hides its name-sake, the snow-drop flower,</br>Why walk forth thus mysteriously?</br>Dear girl, I ask thee seriously.</br>Thy cheek is pale, thy locks are wild—</br>Ah, think, how big thou art with child!—</br>Tho' the baron's red cloak thro' the land hath no fellow,</br>Thou should'st not thus venture without an umbrella!

Dost thou wander to the field of graves</br>Where the elder its spectral branches waves?</br>And will thy hurried footsteps halt</br>Where thy mother sleeps in the silent vault?</br>Where the stranger pauses long to explore</br>The emblems quaint of heraldic lore,</br>Where tho' the lines are tarnished and dim,</br>Thy mother's features stare gaunt and grim,</br>And grinning skull, and transverse bone,</br>And the names of warriors dead and gone</br>Mark Sir Leoline's burial stone;</br>Thither go not, or I deem almost</br>That thou wilt frighten thy mother's ghost!

Or wilt thou wend to the huge oak-tree,</br>And, kneeling down upon thy knee,</br>Number the beads of thy rosary?</br>Nine beads of gold and a tenth of pearl,</br>And a prayer with each, my lovely girl,</br>Nine, and one, shalt thou record,</br>Nine to the virgin and one to the Lord!</br>The pearls are ten times one to behold,</br>And ten times nine are the beads of gold,</br>Methinks 'tis hard of the friar to ask</br>On a night like this so weary a task!

'Tis pleasant — 'tis pleasant, in summer time,</br>In the green wood to spell the storied rhyme,</br>When the light winds above 'mong the light leaves are singing,</br>And the song of the birds thro' your heart is ringing,</br>'Tis pleasant — 'tis pleasant, when happily humming</br>To the flowers below the blythe bee is coming!—</br>When the rivulet coy, and ashamed to be seen,</br>Is heard where it hides 'mong the grass-blades green,</br>When the light of the moon and each sweet starry islet</br>Gives a charm more divine to the long summer twilight,</br>When the breeze o'er the blossomy hawthorn comes cheerful,</br>'Tis pleasant — with heart — ah, how happy! — tho' fearful,</br>With heaven-beaming eyes, where tears come, while smiles glisten</br>To the lover's low vows in the silence to listen!

'Tis pleasant too, on a fine spring day</br>(A month before the month of May)</br>To pray for a lover that's far away!</br>But, Christabel, I cannot see</br>The powerful cause that sways with thee</br>Thus with a face all waxen white,</br>To wander forth on a winter night.

The snow hath ceased, dear lady meek,</br>But the night is chill and bleak!—</br>And clouds are passing swift away</br>Below the moon so old and gray—</br>The crescent moon, like a bark of pearl,</br>That lies so calm on the billowy whirl;—</br>Rapidly — rapidly</br>With the blast,</br>Clouds of ebony</br>Wander fast,</br>And one the maiden hath fixed her eyes on,</br>Hath pass'd o'er the moon, and is near the horizon!</br>Ah Christabel, I dread it, I dread it,</br>That the clouds of shame</br>Will darken and gather</br>O'er the maiden's name,</br>Who chances unwedded</br>To give birth to a child, and knows not its father!

One — Two — Three — Four — Five — Six — Seven — Eight — Nine — Ten — Eleven!—</br>Tempest or calm — moonshine or shower,</br>The castle clock still tolls the hour,</br>And the cock awakens, and echoes the sound,</br>And is answered by the owls around—</br>And at every measured tone</br>You may hear the old baron grunt and groan;</br>'Tis a thing of wonder, and fright, and fear,</br>The mastiff-bitch's moans to hear—</br>And the aged cow in her stall that stands</br>And is milked each morning by female hands</br>(That the baron's breakfast of milk and bread</br>May be brought betimes to the old man's bed</br>Who often gives, while he is dressing,</br>His Christabel a father's blessing)</br>That aged cow, as each stroke sounds slow,</br>Answers it with a plaintive low!</br>And the baron old, who is ill at rest,</br>Curses the favourite cat for a pest—</br>For let him pray, or let him weep,</br>She mews thro' all the hours of sleep—</br>Till morning comes with its pleasant beams,</br>And the cat is at rest, and the baron dreams!

Let it rain, however fast,</br>Rest from rain will come at last,</br>And the blaze that strongest flashes</br>Sinks at last, and ends in ashes!</br>But sorrow from the human heart</br>And mists of care will they depart?</br>I know not, and cannot tell,</br>Saith the lady Christabel—</br>But I feel my bosom swell!</br>In my spirit I behold</br>A lady — call her firm, not bold—</br>Standing lonely by the burn</br>—Strange feelings thro' her breast and brain</br>Shoot with a sense of madness and pain.</br>Ah Christabel return, return,</br>Let me not call on thee in vain!</br>Think, lady dear, if thou art drowned</br>That thy body will be found,</br>What anguish will thy spirit feel,</br>When it must to all reveal</br>What the spell binds thee to conceal!</br>How the baron's heart will knock 'gainst his chest</br>When the stake is driven into thy breast,</br>When thy body to dust shall be carelessly flung,</br>And over the dead no dirge be sung,</br>No friend in mourning vesture dight,</br>No lykewake sad — no tapered rite!—

Return, return thy home to bless,</br>Daughter of good Sir Leoline;</br>In that chamber a recess</br>Known to no other eye than thine,</br>Contains the powerful wild-flower wine</br>That often cheer'd thy mother's heart,</br>Lady, lovely as thou art</br>Return, and ere thou dost undress</br>And lie down in thy nakedness</br>Repair to thy secret and favourite haunt</br>And drink the wine as thou art wont!</br>Hard to uncork and bright to decant.

My merry girl — she drinks — she drinks,</br>Faster she drinks and faster,</br>My brain reels round as I see her whirl,</br>She hath turned on her heel with a sudden twirl;—</br>Wine, wine is a cure for every disaster,</br>For when sorrow wets the eye</br>Yet the heart within is dry,</br>Sweet maid upon the bed she sinks—</br>May her dreams be light, and her rest be deep!</br>Good angels guard her in her sleep!</br>
